docs.lead_paragraph: “Brain training” games have become big business, but the research is still unclear about whether they improve your brain over all.

headline.main: Can Video Games Fend Off Mental Decline?

docs.abstract: Neuroscientist Adam Gazzaley's research on games that are designed to help older people fend off mental decline stands out in a growing industry for so-called 'brain training' games, which are largely controversial; Gazzaley's work commands respect from even the harshest critics, and he has helped company Akili produce game Project: Evo, which is now in process of acquiring Food and Drug Administration approval.
docs.snippet: “Brain training” games have become big business, but the research is still unclear about whether they improve your brain over all.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ellen Langer’s experiments have shown that mental attitudes might reverse some ravages of old age. Now she wants to test that same radical principle on cancer.

headline.main: What if Age Is Nothing but a Mind-Set?

docs.abstract: Bruce Grierson article focuses on Ellen Langer, psychologist who showed that mental attitudes might reverse some of effects of old age, and is now studying whether same principle will work with cancer.
docs.snippet: Ellen Langer’s experiments have shown that mental attitudes might reverse some ravages of old age. Now she wants to test that same radical principle on cancer.

docs.lead_paragraph: Requirements for isolating people who had contact with Ebola patients, like those announced in New York and New Jersey, could dissuade Americans from working at the front lines of the epidemic.

headline.main: New Ebola Quarantine Protocol Seen as Barrier to Volunteers
headline.print_headline: New Protocol Seen as Barrier to Volunteers

docs.abstract: Vast majority of medical professionals who have been fighting Ebola in West Africa say tougher restrictions, like those adopted by New York and New Jersey, could cripple volunteers' efforts at the front lines of the epidemic; federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention sets baseline for recommendation standards on Ebola, but state and local officials have prerogative to tighten the regimen as they see fit.
docs.snippet: Requirements for isolating people who had contact with Ebola patients, like those announced in New York and New Jersey, could dissuade Americans from working at the front lines of the epidemic.

docs.lead_paragraph: Friends and former classmates of Dr. Craig Spencer, who tested positive for Ebola in New York, described him as driven and with an unshakable belief in helping others no matter the place.

headline.main: Ebola Patient in New York Is Called a Doctor at Ease in Danger
headline.print_headline: Ebola Patient in New York Is Called a Doctor at Ease in Danger

docs.abstract: Friends and former classmates of Dr Craig Spencer, first New Yorker to test positive for Ebola virus, describe him as driven and with unshakable belief in helping others no matter the consequences; they are outraged by comments made by New York Gov Andrew M Cuomo suggesting that Spencer put people at risk by not behaving as if under quarantine.
docs.snippet: Friends and former classmates of Dr. Craig Spencer, who tested positive for Ebola in New York, described him as driven and with an unshakable belief in helping others no matter the place.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The young doctor diagnosed with Ebola in New York City is a big-hearted man with a serious interest in international emergency medicine and a flair for languages, yet his friends call him "a goofball."

headline.main: NY Doctor With Ebola a Serious Student With Funny Side, Friends Say
headline.print_headline: NY Doctor With Ebola a Serious Student With Funny Side, Friends Say

docs.snippet: The young doctor diagnosed with Ebola in New York City is a big-hearted man with a serious interest in international emergency medicine and a flair for languages, yet his friends call him "a goofball."

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Craig Spencer, 33, traveled with Doctors Without Borders to Burundi, Congo and Rwanda before going to Guinea.

headline.main: Neighbors Say Ebola Patient Is Fast to Lend a Helping Hand
headline.print_headline: Neighbors Say Patient Is Fast to Lend a Helping Hand

docs.abstract: Friends and neighbors of Ebola patient Dr Craig Spencer in Hamilton Heights section of Upper Manhattan say he is friendly and hard-working.
docs.snippet: Dr. Craig Spencer, 33, traveled with Doctors Without Borders to Burundi, Congo and Rwanda before going to Guinea.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Kia Gregory, Rose Hackman, William K. Rashbaum and Tatiana Schlossberg.

headline.main: Text to Text | 'The Catcher in the Rye' and 'The Case for Delayed Adulthood'

docs.abstract: A passage from the novel paired with a recent Sunday Review article that might offer a new way to think about the line between adolescence and adulthood — and about whether, and how, “Catcher” still has something to say to teenagers.
docs.snippet: A passage from the novel paired with a recent Sunday Review article that might offer a new way to think about the line between adolescence and adulthood — and about whether, and how, “Catcher” still has something to say to teenagers.

docs.lead_paragraph: A problem is that mobile robots now lack the human levels of dexterity required in medicine and health care.

headline.main: Scientists Consider Repurposing Robots for Ebola

docs.abstract: Robotics scientists are pondering whether robotic technologies deployed in rescue and disaster situations should be quickly repurposed to help contain Ebola epidemic; problem is that mobile robots now lack the human levels of dexterity required in medicine and health care.
docs.snippet: A problem is that mobile robots now lack the human levels of dexterity required in medicine and health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many established spas and retreats are retooling their offerings to attract the same target: wealthy, successful and highly stressed-out executives.

headline.seo: Health Spas Aimed at Teaching Stressed Executives to Unwind

docs.abstract: Many established spas and retreats have turned their focus to fitness in effort to appeal to wealthy, highly stressed-out executives; VeraVia in California charges $1,000 roughly a day for its services, which include sessions with nutritionists, physical activities, massages and much more.
docs.snippet: Many established spas and retreats are retooling their offerings to attract the same target: wealthy, successful and highly stressed-out executives.

headline.main: Renee Zellweger and the Question of Aging

docs.abstract: Has the use of plastic surgery gone too far? What does it mean (or take) to age gracefully, especially in the public eye?
docs.snippet: Has the use of plastic surgery gone too far? What does it mean (or take) to age gracefully, especially in the public eye?
